text:
Pancreatitis, acute
   Assessment:
   Pt with h/o etoh abuse (6
large
 hard liquor drinks per day). Panc
   enymes/LFTs elevated. CT remarkable for pancreatitis and fatty liver
   changes. Lactate 8.1 in ED. + Bowel sounds in all 4 quads; abdomen
   obese/distended.
   Action:
   NPO; 2L NS boluses; NS maintenance fluid for several hours now
   maintenance fluid of D5W with 3 amps of Bicarb
   Response:
   Patient
s urine output has decreased and continues to require
   aggressive fluid resuscitation.
   Plan:
   Remain NPO; fluid resuscitation; continue to monitor labs; surgery
   consult now since second [**Location (un) 118**] of CT shows 30% of pancreas necrotic.
   Gastrointestinal bleed, upper (Melena, GI Bleed, GIB)
   Assessment:
   Pt presented with L NGT not putting out any drainage; no melena/no
   emesis.
   Action:
   Intubated for endoscopy
 patient was extremely difficult/impossible to
   sedate properly for procedure, necessitating large doses of sedatives
   (see metavision and [**Month (only) **]); endoscopy; resent crit. On
   Octreotide/protonix gtts.
   Response:
   Pt became barely sedated after multiple gtts initiated; able to
   tolerate endoscopy. Repeat crit stable, slightly decreased but in
   setting of multiple fluid boluses. Endoscopy showed multiple gastric
   erosion sites. No active bleeding site indentified. NGT D/Ced. No
   evidence of varices so Octreotide gtt D/Ced.
   Plan:
   NPO; monitor crit closely; continue protonix gtt until at least
   tomorrow per GI.
   Alcohol withdrawal (including delirium tremens, DTs, seizures)
   Assessment:
   Pt drinks daily in large quantities, hard liquor. Reports at times,
   feeling tremulous at home if he has not had a drink in a while. Pt last
   drank night of [**5-16**]. Patient appears anxious, tachycardic, tremulous,
   slightly diaphoretic and confused as to date.
   Action:
   Followed CIWA scale. Patient
s CIWA scale 11. Ativan administered,
   later diazepam when Ativan discontinued.
   Response:
   Patient slightly less tremulous; remembers date and recalls location
   ([**Hospital1 **]; ICU) better than he did when first presenting to SICU.
   Plan:
   Continue to follow CIWA scale and treat with diazepam when CIWA scale
   above 10. Monitor closely.
